newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU wins changes in Sega games licences.
newsitem.headline: EU wins changes in Sega games licences.

text.p: The European Commission said on Thursday it had obtained that Japan's video-game company Sega Enterprises Ltd change its licensing agreements to allow independent companies to develop more games compatible with its console systems.

This is the second time in less than a month that the Commission claims victory in obtaining concessions from video game giants. On July 22 it announced that Nintendo Co Ltd, another Japanese company, had also modified its licensing agreements.
Under the new agreements, there are no limits on the number of games that a Sega licensee may release on the market and prior quality approvals by Sega are no longer required.
"The European Commission informed Sega that its redrafted standard licensing agreements are now compatible with European Union competition law," it said in a statement.

"The Commission considers that Sega's new licensing agreements will allow much greater competition on the market for Sega compatible games, and that this will be to the immediate benefit of European consumers", it added.
Like Nintendo, Sega modified the agreements after consultation with both the Commission, the EU's competition watchdog, and Britain's Department of Trade and Industry.

Sega will be able to subject the release of the games to its prior approval if a licensee wants to use its trademark. The agreements also provide that the games will be tested, possibly by an independent body, before commercial release for bug and compatibility checking. -- Amelia Torres 322 287684
